Hey Reav3 can you share in your opinion why in general non humanoids aren't as resonant as humanoids, it seems to be a trend in gaming in general since like even in WoW people greatly prefer humanoids like Draenei or Elves over like say taurens or goblins

I think it's largely due to people feeling like the can relate to the Champion. Many people feel they can relate to human characters and so they like them more. If you take it one step further you will see that even among the humans more people are drawn to the "normal" humans. or humans that don't have god like powers, since that is even more relatable. Lee Sin, Yassuo, Jhin, Akali, Miss Fortune are all extremely popular and they all share the fact that they are not only humans but humans without any super powers, they all just got to be Champions from being super bad ass humans, rather then from some magical gift or godly power.

To be honest, not being able to relate to non-human/humanoid champions isn't much of an issue for me (or the vast majority of your playerbase for that matter).

1. I enjoy the primal nature of champions like Cho'Gath and Rek'Sai.
2. When they're as intelligent and complex as Aurelion Sol, you can still relate to them as though they're human.
3. I enjoy the mythology behind some of the more elusive creatures (or the ones that don't leave many survivors) - human mythology is full of monstrous non-human beings that quite frequently show up in pop culture.

Writing lore for these creatures really wouldn't be that hard. Write it as a field guide to monsters. Write it in 2nd person from the perspective of its prey. Write it as though we're watching a David Attenborough documentary on Xer'Sai hunting maneuvers.

While I understand its not a issue for you, or me tbh. We do see that it is a issue for the vast majority of our players, I was just commenting on why I think that is.

Here is the link that one of our data scientists put out about Champion popularity awhile ago

https://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/2017/11/champ-popularity-mixing-math-art/

Non-Humanoid Champions definitely get played much less then humanoid Champions by a majority of the playerbase. 

This doesn't mean we shouldn't make them as they do make the cast overall feel more dynamic when we have them, even if they are less popular

I feel like it's pretty obvious that there are numerous large factors when it comes to causing popularity in a champion. I wouldn't be the least bit surprised if the correlation between unpopular and non-human is rather indirect and is in fact much more due to Riot using non-humans mostly to represent unusual or niche gameplay, often making such champions rather unfriendly to new players.

Riot rarely supports these non-human champions well in the lore and skin departments as well. And of course there's the sexiness factor. Lots of people prefer champions that they find sexually attractive. Non-humans can be sexy too, though admittedly it's not as easy to make happen, but Riot doesn't seem to make any effort in this regard, further handicapping non-human champions when it comes to popularity. This part also basically applies to cuteness just the same.

And to top it all off, non-humans can absolutely be highly relatable. Yet again, Riot doesn't seem to try to make this happen at all either. I get that it's asking for more and/or better work to make a non-human champion that's likely to be popular, but I think Riot should be aiming to do it anyways.

How much of any of that actually has to do with whether the champion is human or humanoid or non-human/humanoid? Most of the champions in the unpopular quadrant are either really old or niche champions that Riot gimped because they became meta.

Champion loyalty isn't really a thing anymore. Lore/archetype and gameplay/champion popularity aren't nearly as connected as they used to be. Some of my favorite champions haven't been viable for 6-12 months. You can't use champion popularity to inform decisions pertaining to what champions you rework or create because it's so incredibly warped by balance.

Camille, for example, would have been sitting in the Niche/Unpopular quadrant for probably 6 months but now I can almost guarantee that she's center-right or top-right. I can guarantee that Skarner shot up a fair bit for a decent chunk of the first half of Season 8.

EDIT: Typical of Riot to give me an old table so that I'm stuck trying to remember what the state of the meta was back then while the Rioter gets to draw from internal data.

https://i.gyazo.com/6c678d4553180d8fc8bca241c7faa014.png

Breaking that down into just Junglers (my main role and the one I can recall the most information about) it's painfully obvious how much a lot of that has shifted over the course of 2 seasons.

Give us a Poro champ and watch that shit change overnight.

{{item:2052}}

This does interact with skins in some way at least. If a champion is less relatable **and** less played obviously its more opportunity cost to make skins for that champion than the beloved humans. This isn't bashing the fact that happens, it makes sense for both consumer and producer, and I know you guys are conscientiously trying to support the less played champions with skins too. Just an observation, maybe it less interacts with designing champions but more with designing cosmetics. Its harder to make a non humanoid have more desirable thematic and  have more a playerbase to buy said thematics.

Do you think non-humanoid champions would be more popular if they received the same amount of promo/skin/lore/event attention as some of the humans you listed? Do you think the amount of content these champions receive contributes to why they are more popular? I know a lot of non-humanoid champions receive less skins, have needed/been updated, were not in good gameplay states for significant periods of time, and are generally outdated.
